{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3464014,"name":"David","username":"DavidMasin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/davidmasin/{size}/205339_2.png","created_at":"2024-12-27T19:42:39.420Z","cooked":"

Our team has been having an ongoing debate for at least 3 years, and I’d love to hear your opinions on this. The discussion revolves around whether or not swerve modules should be greased.
(We have 2 swerves: WCP’s Swerve X Flipped and Swerve X (non Flipped), but I believe the discussion should be in general about greasing swerve modules or not)

We have two mentors with very different perspectives:

  • One mentor firmly believes that swerve modules should always be greased. They argue that grease reduces friction, prolongs the life of the gears and bearings, and ensures smooth operation.
  • The other mentor says greasing isn’t necessary and might even cause more harm than good. Their reasoning is that grease can attract dirt and debris, leading to increased wear and more frequent maintenance.

Both mentors have valid points, and it’s sparked a lot of curiosity within the team. We want to know:
What’s your approach to greasing swerve modules?

  • Do you grease your modules?
  • If so, how do you handle maintenance to prevent issues like contamination?
  • If not, how do you ensure smooth operation and longevity of the components?

Let’s settle this debate—or at least gather some good insights from this awesome community!

I would love to hear some “official” answers from Vendors like WCP, SDS and TTB!
Looking forward to your responses!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-12-27T19:42:39.420Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":160,"reads":449,"readers_count":448,"score":954.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":477424,"topic_slug":"should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules","display_username":"David","primary_group_name":"FUN","flair_name":"FUN","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/3/5/3523e759b0af37a7757142a8b2aa79b31f1a47c4.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":60,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52686,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules/477424/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3464017,"name":"","username":"Ugydukin","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/u/278dde/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-12-27T19:45:47.071Z","cooked":"

I believe the most adopted solution to this is greasing your modules along with using dust covers, which someone has designed for practically every module. I definitely agree with mentor one though.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-12-27T19:45:47.071Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":423,"readers_count":422,"score":149.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":477424,"topic_slug":"should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65614,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"ugydukin"},"post_url":"/t/should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules/477424/2","custom_user_title":"ugydukin","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3464018,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2024-12-27T19:46:06.912Z","cooked":"

Grease, cover, clean regularly.

If you don’t grease, budget for new gears on a very regular basis.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-12-27T19:46:40.521Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":423,"readers_count":422,"score":384.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":477424,"topic_slug":"should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":19}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules/477424/3","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":16},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":19,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3464019,"name":"Brian Wagg","username":"cad321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-12-27T19:46:31.600Z","cooked":"

As per WCP’s own words, grease your swerve modules. Other swerve vendors offer similar advice.

To help prevent debris from getting into our modules, we ensure we put a printed tube plug in the end of the tubing on each corner of the modules, and you can also 3d print guards/covers to help prevent debris from getting in them.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-12-27T19:46:31.600Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":419,"readers_count":418,"score":238.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":477424,"topic_slug":"should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules","display_username":"Brian Wagg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wcproducts.com/wcp-swervex/misc/maintenance","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Maintenance | WCP Swerve X","clicks":15}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":10}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19532,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Brian Wagg"},"post_url":"/t/should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules/477424/4","custom_user_title":"Brian Wagg","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":9},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":10,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3464020,"name":"s-neff","username":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png","created_at":"2024-12-27T19:48:51.149Z","cooked":"

Yes. A little bit of grease (reduce friction), not a lot of grease (collect carpet bits).

How about a dry lubricant? Has anyone given that a try?

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-12-27T19:52:19.515Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":378,"readers_count":377,"score":110.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":477424,"topic_slug":"should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules","display_username":"James","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3182,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Alumni Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules/477424/6","custom_user_title":"Alumni Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3464031,"name":"Zachary","username":"Zatack7","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zatack7/{size}/175437_2.png","created_at":"2024-12-27T20:03:59.155Z","cooked":"

Yes.

Do swerve modules need grease? General Forum
Yes, it is very important to grease the gears on your modules. The exact grease you use is not very critical. When greasing the gears turn wheel by hand to evenly distribute the grease throughout the gears. Then be sure to wipe of the extra globs of gears so it doesn’t get flung. We (2910) grease our gears before every event, but we are putting many events worth of driving on our robots between events.

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1YON4IBr12W_1YUXMwIQCAXqeExhDmy0c/view

Google Drive","clicks":4},{"url":"https://docs.revrobotics.com/ion-build-system/build-guides/maxswerve-module-assembly","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"MAXSwerve Module Assembly | ION BUILD SYSTEM","clicks":1},{"url":"https://docs.wcproducts.com/wcp-swerve-x2/misc/maintenance","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Maintenance | WCP Swerve X2","clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/do-swerve-modules-need-grease/446914/3","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Do swerve modules need grease?","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":13}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53819,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"ban the rev 40a breaker"},"post_url":"/t/should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules/477424/7","custom_user_title":"ban the rev 40a breaker","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":10},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":13,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3464032,"name":"Nick Foote","username":"Footie","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/footie/{size}/218325_2.png","created_at":"2024-12-27T20:08:56.727Z","cooked":"

We first got our swerve drive during the off season and didn’t grease them properly, and after only a few couple competitions, all our gears had been turned into pointy little throwing stars.

So now we liberally grease, try to keep stuff from getting inside, and de-grease and clean every 10-15 hours of drive time or one competition.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-12-27T20:31:01.261Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":307,"readers_count":306,"score":111.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":477424,"topic_slug":"should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules","display_username":"Nick Foote","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":8103,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Nick Foote - 2102 Team Paradox - Engineering Mentor and Founding Student"},"post_url":"/t/should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules/477424/8","custom_user_title":"Nick Foote - 2102 Team Paradox - Engineering Mentor and Founding Student","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3464033,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2024-12-27T20:08:57.105Z","cooked":"

We have had a ton of threads on this already, and it is on the product pages as @Zatack7 points out.

Search is a powerful tool.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-12-27T20:13:06.112Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":300,"readers_count":299,"score":105.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":477424,"topic_slug":"should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules/477424/9","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3464037,"name":"David","username":"DavidMasin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/davidmasin/{size}/205339_2.png","created_at":"2024-12-27T20:17:47.997Z","cooked":"

I just want to point out that we are aware vendors recommend greasing the modules, and we understand the reasoning behind it. However, one issue we’ve observed is that greasing the modules can lead to a lot of dust and debris (like aluminum shavings or carpet fibers) getting inside the module, which can cause wear or performance issues.

The main question we’re struggling with is: how much grease should you actually apply to each module? I haven’t been able to find any specific recommendations for the amount when looking online. Too much grease could attract more debris, while too little might not provide sufficient lubrication.

The second question is: how do you prevent contaminants like aluminum shavings or carpet fibers from getting inside the module and sticking to the grease? This seems to be a recurring challenge, especially in FRC environments where there’s a lot of fine debris flying around.

Would love to hear how other teams are handling this! Any tips, tricks, or maintenance routines to balance these issues would be greatly appreciated.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-12-27T20:17:47.997Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":272,"readers_count":271,"score":74.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":477424,"topic_slug":"should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules","display_username":"David","primary_group_name":"FUN","flair_name":"FUN","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/3/5/3523e759b0af37a7757142a8b2aa79b31f1a47c4.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":60,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52686,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules/477424/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3464040,"name":"Ardiano Works","username":"MSU2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/msu2000/{size}/190139_2.png","created_at":"2024-12-27T20:23:45.702Z","cooked":"
  1. Yes we grease it.
  2. Wheel cover should do protect the wheel drive train from huge debris.
  3. Applying the right amount of torque ensure there is no binding. The right amount and type of grease also help. You don’t need a blob of grease, light coat is enough. Loctite, proper amount and application ensure everything is in its place. I have Rev Module that has 10 hrs total heavy use that all the drivetrain still looks good.
","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-12-27T20:23:45.702Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":246,"readers_count":245,"score":64.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":477424,"topic_slug":"should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules","display_username":"Ardiano Works","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57747,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules/477424/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3464054,"name":"Troy Dietz","username":"troy_dietz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/troy_dietz/{size}/135768_2.png","created_at":"2024-12-27T21:07:13.867Z","cooked":"

I’ve seen many teams use it, and have mostly observed poor results from that. Lots of pointy teeth more quickly than they should have shown up.

Dry spray lube is not intended for the high pressure that gear teeth experience. It’s for things like window sliders or between leaf spring leafs. It might delay wearing through the coating on aluminum gears, but you should make an effort to use the proper grease until it’s no longer sustainable, then resort to dry products.

Most NLGI grade 2 viscosity stuff works fine.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-12-27T21:07:13.867Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":215,"readers_count":214,"score":108.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":477424,"topic_slug":"should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules","display_username":"Troy Dietz","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":3182,"username":"Crebb","name":"James","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/crebb/{size}/223948_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"❤️ conflict-free COTS"},"post_url":"/t/should-you-grease-your-swerve-modules/477424/12","custom_user_title":"❤️ conflict-free COTS","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3464100,"name":"s-neff","username":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png","created_at":"2024-12-27T23:24:08.685Z","cooked":"
DavidMasin:

how much grease should you actually apply to each module

Can barely tell it’s there

DavidMasin:

how do you prevent contaminants like aluminum shavings or carpet fibers from getting inside the module and sticking to the grease?

Clean them out once a season.

If we meet our practice goals for this year, might need to clean them before the first in-season comp.

To be clear, we clean parts before assembly and we don’t cut parts over the robot - so there’s a second layer of general environmental considerations that you can take there. I wish we did a better job vacuuming our practice area.

DavidMasin:

The other mentor says greasing isn’t necessary and might even cause more harm than good. Their reasoning is that grease can attract dirt and debris, leading to increased wear and more frequent maintenance.

Wrong wrong wrong wrong wrong wrong.

This is what happens to swerve modules if you run them without grease (2 events in this case). You do not want your swerve modules to look like this.

img_03631920×2560 223 KB

I’ll leave James’s advice here. Syringes to apply grease were highly useful.

FRC95 2022 Build Thread FRC Open Alliance
Happy McReVexmas everyone! We are excited to begin robot assembly in earnest now. [image] Let’s talk about drivetrain lubrication. There are a lot of options, most of which have been executed successfully over the years. We have used dryfilm type lubricants on chains and gears before. On chains dryfilm has been foolproof for us, we use Chain Saver. We also used this successfully on drivetrain gears for a few years. But… if you lapse on maintenance for open aluminum gears with a dry film the…
FRC 95 The Grasshoppers 2023 Build Thread FRC Open Alliance
Excellent and thoughtful questions! Let’s see what we can do… I/we prefer using a syringe because they are small, light, and dispense a perfectly sized bead of grease that avoids excess squeeze-out or waste of grease. For extra process control you can measure how much grease should be applied to each device and specify that in a checklist (e.g. 2mL to swerve drive gears, 3mL in arm gearbox, etc.) In my own shop I have a grease gun that I use for conventional Zerk fittings and to fill syringes…

I would suggests that you use 3d printed covers to prevent debris from entering you modules, not fail to grease them.

No grease: The gear faces are sliding against other gear faces of the same hardness, under pressure – as a regular part of normal, ordinary operation.

Grease, and you don’t keep things clean: The gear faces occasionally have a bit of carpet or maybe aluminum (against a typically steel gear) run through, under the same pressure (less anything taken up by the grease).

You’re ahead of the game even if you don’t clean the gears.
